entry.title: Re: Direct link to LMS custom pages
entry.content:
Dear @mbshatto 

Currently, there is no way to generate the direct link to a custom page using the generate link tool. It was never a part of initial scope of the tool's design. However, based on customer feedback, it can be considered as a potential enhancement for future updates.

  • At present, the standard way to access the new custom pages is via the dropdown (which is kinda concealed) and hence making a custom card or banner as an entry point for custom pages is more of a workaround to make them more visible and discoverable on the LHP. 
  • "Links" anyway (even in the legacy) were maintained by customers as they can change and hence break the navigation. Not just the copied URLs to the custom pages but many links for that matter that customers put in those cards. We have Link type custom cards (supporting URL's) that can also be dynamic and the onus of maintaining and updating those links afresh is on the admin managing those custom cards or banners."

At this point, in case this is desired to have a custom page link, it's necessary to navigate the to custom page and copy it from the browser Address Bar. Still, this link may stop working later on as this is not the ideal way to navigate to a custom page. For further details, please refer to the KBA - 3544350 - Unable to Generate Direct Link to Custom Page in SAP SuccessFactors Learning - SAP for Me.

Thank you,

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite - Connecting to S/4HANA Private Cloud OData with OAuth (Client Credentials)
entry.content:
Introduction

Modern integration scenarios increasingly rely on secure, token-based connectivity. In SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration, the OData receiver adapters (V2 and V4) support a range of authentication mechanisms‚Äîsuch as Basic Authentication, Client Certificate, and OAuth 2.0. Out of the box, OAuth-based connectivity is common for public cloud services, where provider endpoints and identity flows are standardized and well-documented.

But what if your OData endpoint sits in a private cloud or behind corporate network boundaries, and it‚Äôs protected by OAuth 2.0? This introduction sets the scene for a practical, step-by-step walkthrough that shows how to connect SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration to private cloud OData services using OAuth 2.0 with the client credentials grant type. You‚Äôll learn how to enable OAuth for OData services, define the OAuth client in SAP S/4HANA, and wire everything up in SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration so your flows can obtain and use access tokens seamlessly.

 

Prepare the SAP S/4HANA

Enable OAuth authentication for Odata services

V2

  • Access transaction /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE for OData service administration
  • Locate your target OData V2 service in the Service Catalog view
  • Verify the service is properly activated and running
  • Click the OAuth button from the available menu option
  • Select a package to store the to be created OAuth scope
  • Check the status for successful activation
  • All created objects are available via the assigned package (SE80)

V4

  • Access transaction /IWFND/V4_ADMIN for OData service administration
  • Locate your target OData V4 service in the Service Groups view
  • Verify the service is properly activated and running
  • Click the OAuth button from the available menu option
  • Enable Oauth
  • Validate activation status and scope

Create integration user

Perform this step only if no technical integration user exists or if the scenario requires a dedicated user. If a suitable user is already available, reuse it and adjust its authorizations as needed.

  • Navigate to SAP transaction SU01
  • Enter a user name and select the create user button 
  • Define a last name for the user in the address section
  • Navigate to the ‚ÄúLogon Data‚Äù section
  • Set the user type to ‚ÄúSystem", define a password and save the changes

Create an OAuth client

Proceed with this step only if an OAuth client has not yet been created for the designated system user. If a client already exists, reuse it and update its configuration details as needed.

  • Navigate to SAP transaction /nSOAUTH2
  • Select ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù and then select ‚ÄúCreate..."
  • Set the Client Type to ‚ÄúConfidential‚Äù or ‚ÄúPublic‚Äù based upon the general IT security governance rules, define the OAuth 2.0 Client ID. Keep in mind that this has to be equivalent to the previously created or existing user. Provide a description and set the token lifetime according to the internal governance rules. Select ‚ÄúNext"
  • The goal for this client is to authenticate itself using client id and secret therefore deselect option ‚ÄúSSL Client Certificate‚Äù then select ‚ÄúNext"
  • Deselect ‚ÄúGrant Type SAML 2.0 Bearer Active‚Äù and select ‚ÄúGrant Type Client Credentials Active‚Äù hence the goal is to activate the client for grant type client credentials. Select ‚ÄúNext‚Äù.
  • Add the OAuth 2.0 Scope ID of the OData service to be called and select ‚ÄúNext‚Äù
  • Finally review the settings and select ‚ÄúFinish‚Äù. The result should look like this.

Create authorization role

This step is only necessary if either no role exists or if it‚Äôs required to have a dedicated role per integration. If there is an existing role you should use it and in case necessary adjust its details.  
 
The instructions focus on the integration aspects. Therefore role definitions and the assignments of service related authorisations are not covered. To fine-grain authorisations for OAuth clients to scopes use of authorisation object S_SCOPE.

Configure SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration

In SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration, the configuration provided with this blog includes a downloadable iFlow that mirrors the setup described below and can be used as a reference template, then adapted to your needs. The iFlow consists of one main flow and two local subprocesses.

For demonstration purposes, the main flow is triggered by a timer and first checks whether a valid access token is already available. If a token exists, the main flow delegates processing to the subprocess responsible for invoking the target OData service. If no token is found, the flow requests a new OAuth token and, once obtained, proceeds to call the OData service via the same subprocess. This structure isolates token handling from service invocation, making the solution easier to reuse, maintain, and extend for different scenarios.

To optimize performance and reduce load on the S/4HANA backend, the access token is cached in a local variable within the iFlow, avoiding unnecessary token requests on each run. In the rare event the backend invalidates or terminates the token, the iFlow supports an on-demand refresh via a dedicated header parameter. While a production-ready setup could automate this with an exception subprocess that detects token-related errors and triggers a controlled refresh, note that‚Äîfor demo purposes‚Äîforced token refresh as part of error handling is not covered in this blog. Alternatively, you can manually re-trigger the interface using the same header parameter to force a token refresh when needed.

Finally, the iFlow issues a request to the target OData service. To fully leverage the OData receiver adapter‚Äôs capabilities, ensure you upload the service‚Äôs EDMX metadata file. With the EDMX in place, the adapter can discover and configure resources (entity sets, operations) correctly and orchestrate backend calls automatically. Without it, resources cannot be resolved properly, you are forced to maintain endpoints and authorization details manually, and the adapter cannot automatically invoke the backend service as intended.

IFlow template

The iFlow template can be downloaded from the following GitHub repository.

entry.title: Re: How to export Customer credit segment data?
entry.content:
Dear @MSSAP07,

Option 1: Display Credit Account Data (F4825) and export to spreadsheet

Use the list/reporting app that is meant to display credit master data and then export.

  1. Open Display Credit Account Data (F4825)

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/083777d1580a41da91e7935d1787b155.html

  1. Filter for your population and Go
  2. In the results table:
    • Use Settings Columns or Adapt Filters/Columns, depending on your UI
    • Add columns for:
      • Credit Segment
      • Credit Limit + Currency
      • Risk Class
      • Credit Check Rule
  3. Use Export Spreadsheet

Option 2: Use the standard Credit Management Master Data API (OData)

SAP provides a dedicated API for credit management master data Credit Management Master Data (API_CRDTMBUSINESSPARTNER)

More details below:

https://api.sap.com/api/API_CRDTMBUSINESSPARTNER/resource/Credit_Account_Collaterals

To use it in Public Cloud you set up a Communication Arrangement for communication scenario SAP_COM_0740 that‚Äôs the scenario tied to this API

SAP Notes below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3436543

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3575895

This is the most reliable option if you need repeatable extraction for audits/validation

Option 3: Custom CDS / Custom Analytical Query extract

If you don‚Äôt have the API/scenario available build an extract using released CDS and expose/export it:

  • SAP delivers credit reporting CDS such as I_CreditAccountExtended commonly used for credit reporting

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3315841

  • You can create a Custom CDS View / Custom Analytical Query on released views and then export results or even expose as an external API if needed

Summary:

In Public Cloud the credit segment fields you listed are not part of BP master data export they belong to SAP Credit Management. That‚Äôs why Export Master Data Business Partners won‚Äôt give you Credit Segment / Credit Limit / Risk Class / Rules

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Cutting Through the Complexity: Lease Accounting in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Lease accounting under IFRS 16 and ASC 842 continues to challenge finance and project teams alike. The calculations themselves are straightforward ‚Äî it‚Äôs the classification and operational handling that create complexity.

In SAP Cloud ERP, the Contract and Lease Management (CLM) functionality simplifies this challenge by delivering a standardized, automated approach for both lessee and lessor accounting.

This blog explains how the system supports different lease types ‚Äî and what that means in practical terms for finance teams adopting a clean-core cloud solution.

Lessee Accounting ‚Äì For Companies Using Assets

If your business leases assets such as office space, vehicles, or equipment, you‚Äôre acting as a lessee. The system handles these scenarios through Scope Item 1T6: Lease-In Accounting.

When you activate a lease contract, S/4HANA Cloud automatically:

  • Calculates the Right-of-Use (ROU) asset and lease liability based on future payments.
  • Posts interest expense on the liability and depreciation on the asset each period.
  • Integrates everything into the Universal Journal for full auditability.

From a finance perspective, this means that once the contract data is entered correctly, the system takes care of recognition and periodic postings ‚Äî freeing you from manual calculations or offline models.

IFRS 16 vs ASC 842: Two Frameworks, One Process

  • IFRS 16 treats nearly all leases as finance leases ‚Äî meaning they appear on the balance sheet.
  • ASC 842, used in the US, distinguishes between:
    • Finance leases, where interest and depreciation are shown separately.
    • Operating leases, where the expense appears as a single straight-line amount in the income statement, even though both the asset and liability exist in the background.

Both standards are supported natively. This allows multinational organizations to run a single process while reporting correctly under different frameworks.

Short-Term and Low-Value Exemptions

S/4HANA Cloud also supports the practical exemptions under IFRS 16 ‚Äî for leases under 12 months or of low-value assets. These are recorded but not capitalized, keeping disclosure complete without overstating the balance sheet.

Explore more: SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Contract & Lease Management ‚Äì Simplify and Lower the Cost of Compliance

Lessor Accounting ‚Äì For Companies Providing Assets

Some organizations lease out their own equipment, vehicles, or real estate. In these cases, you‚Äôre the lessor.

The Public Edition supports standard lessor models under both IFRS 16 and ASC 842, helping finance teams recognize income correctly depending on the nature of the lease.

Finance Lease (IFRS 16)

If the lessee effectively takes on most of the risks and rewards of ownership:

  • The asset is replaced by a lease receivable.
  • Income is recognized as interest over the lease term.

Sales-Type Lease (ASC 842)

Used when the lease is effectively a sale at commencement:

  • Revenue and cost of goods sold are recognized immediately.
  • Interest income is then recognized over time.

Direct Financing Lease (ASC 842)

Applied when there is no upfront selling profit:

  • A lease receivable is created.
  • Income arises gradually through interest over the lease period.

In practice, most organizations using CLM in the Public Edition are handling a limited number of such lessor contracts ‚Äî for example, internal leasing of IT assets or vehicles between entities ‚Äî rather than running a large-scale commercial leasing operation.

Learn more: Enabling a Renting Business Model with SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Subscription Billing

Making the Right Call on Lease Type

The most common challenge project teams face is not the posting itself ‚Äî it‚Äôs the classification decision at the start.
The following simple logic can help you decide which path applies:

  1. Are you the user or provider of the asset?
    ‚Üí User ‚Üí Lessee Accounting (Scope Item 1T6)
    ‚Üí Provider ‚Üí Lessor Accounting
  2. Which reporting standard applies?
    • If yes ‚Üí Finance or Sales-Type Lease.
    • If no ‚Üí Operating or Direct Financing Lease.
    • IFRS 16 ‚Üí All leases (except short-term/low-value) are Finance Leases.
    • ASC 842 ‚Üí Determine whether the lease transfers ownership or risk.
  3. Enter the contract in CLM using the relevant Fiori app ‚Äî the system will handle valuation and posting automatically.

Key Takeaways

  • Lessee accounting (Scope Item 1T6) is the core capability in Cloud ERP.
  • The system supports both IFRS 16 and ASC 842 with standard content.
  • Lessor models (Finance, Sales-Type, Direct Financing) are available for entities providing assets.
  • The clean-core approach minimizes maintenance and simplifies audit readiness.

Learn More

  • SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Contract and Lease Management (Public Edition)
  • SAP Community Topic: Finance in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP Learning Hub ‚Äì Lease Accounting Fundamentals
  • SAP Best Practices Explorer ‚Äì Scope Item 1T6

entry.title: Re: Why using the dynamic variant of CALL TRANSFORMATION if the static one can be used?
entry.content:
Another explanation is that maybe the developers have the feeling of being good developers if they use something complex.

I guess that a good developer would:

  1. Respect the development guidelines (and advocate to improve them).
  2. Choose the appropriate technology (e.g. to produce XML, use an XML Transformation language instead of pure ABAP, or eventually XML API).
  3. Code the simplest way.

In the code here, there's no reason to over-complexify the code.

The simplest way is definitely:

       CALL TRANSFORMATION z_xml_abcd
          SOURCE data = gt_ot
          RESULT XML rv_xml_xstring.

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: Traveling with My little Puppy and Finding Balance Beyond Tech :)
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

My name is Marla. I work as a Senior Data and AI Developer, and Today, I‚Äôd like to share a bit about my hobby as a part of the  SAP Community Hobbies series. ü§ó Outside of work, one hobby has become very important to me over the last few years: traveling and exploring the world with my little puppy Carlo üòÉ üê∂

It might sound simple, but it requires a lot of planning and creativity. How I organize my trips has also influenced how I think about systems and processes. Carlo is not just my travel companion. He is part of the journey and the reason many of these experiences exist in the first place.

How and when did I start this hobby?

I did not plan for this to become a hobby. It started naturally when I got Carlo five years ago and realized I did not want to stop traveling or leave him alone while I‚Äôm on vacation ü•π. So naturally, instead of adapting my life to travel, I adapted travel to my life.üòâ

Short trips, nature-focused destinations, dog-friendly cities and countries  ( I can totally recommend Croatia and Italy ), and flexible planning became the default. Over time, this turned into a routine and something I actively look forward to. Together, Carlo, my partner Niklas, and I have discovered many new places, from quiet nature spots to vibrant cities, always at a pace that works for all of us.

 

 

Me and Carlo on the way to attend a workshop in Belgrade- Serbia

 

visiting the stunning Externsteine in the Teutoburg Forest - Germany

 Having the best time in The Hague - the Netherlands

 

What do I love most about it?

The biggest value is presence. Traveling with a dog forces you to slow down. You walk more, you observe more, and you plan less around attractions and more around experiences. It clears my head in a way that very few things do, especially after intense project phases or long weeks in front of screens. It is also grounding. No notifications matter when you are on a forest path with a leash in your hand, or when Carlo decides that a certain spot is worth stopping for.

Challenges and how I deal with them

Traveling with a dog is not always easy. Not every hotel is dog-friendly. Public transport rules vary(For example, in Austria, Carlo has to wear a muzzle when using public transportation üòÖ ). Planning takes more effort, especially across countries. I learned to research carefully, build buffers, and always have a backup plan.

A proud moment

My proudest moments are not big milestones. They are small wins. The first long train trip went smoothly. The first international trip without stress. Finding places where Carlo is relaxed, welcome, and curious rather than overwhelmed.

Those moments tell me that good preparation pays off.

Celebrating a friend's birthday in Zaragoza - Spain

 

 

 

Traviling to Berlin for TechEd 2025

 

 

flying to Mallorca -Spain

 

enjoying a ride in Texel- the Netherlands

Tools and resources for beginners

For anyone starting out, these are essential:

Dog-friendly accommodation platforms and search filters
Basic travel gear such as a good leash, a portable water bowl, and a transport-safe harness
Patience and realistic expectations. You do not need expensive equipment. You need planning and awareness.

 

Chilling at the Hotel in k√ºlingsborn-Germany

 

 

Flying to Spain again üòÑ

 

 

 

Road trips with the car

 

Tips for getting started

Start small.üòâ Begin with day trips, then weekends, then longer journeys. Observe how your dog reacts and adjust. Do not aim for perfection. Aim for learning. The same applies to learning new SAP technologies. Iteration beats overplanning.

How I keep improving

I learn by doing. Each trip teaches me something new. Traveling with Carlo constantly challenges me to be more flexible and attentive. I also exchange tips with other dog owners and travelers. Reflection after each journey helps me improve the next one. Continuous improvement does not need formal training. It needs attention.

Common misconceptions

A common myth is that traveling with a dog is restrictive.In reality, it changes priorities, but it also opens new perspectives. You discover quieter places, nature-focused destinations, and a slower pace that many people are actually looking for.

Visiting Heidelberg

 

 

Carlo in Berlin üòÑ

 

 

Chilling in Mallorca

Where to learn more

There are many blogs and communities focused on dog-friendly travel, especially in Europe and North America. Local communities are often more helpful than large platforms.

The connection to the SAP world

The connection is stronger than it seems.

Traveling with a dog is about systems thinking. You balance constraints, dependencies, timing, and user experience, where the user just happens to have four legs.

In SAP projects, especially in data and AI, we design architectures that must be robust, flexible, and humane. This hobby constantly reminds me that good systems serve real needs, not just technical elegance.It also helps me show up better at work. More focused, more patient, and more grounded.

What is next?

After discovering so many places together, our next big plan is to cross the Atlantic. Carlo and I are preparing for a longer journey, with New York and Toronto at the top of the list. It will be a new level of planning, learning, and adapting, and I am already looking forward to what we will discover next.

Thanks for reading. If you travel with your dog, or if you have found a hobby that helps you disconnect and think better, I would love to hear about it.

 

Hello from Karlsruhe

Coming up  next ü•Å

I am happy to pass the baton to  @HakanHasalman, who will introduce his writing hobby. ü§ó

 

With Love,
Marla & Carlo

entry.title: Re: 6 Steps to an AI Assessment in SAP: Discovery-First Approach
entry.content:
Hi @Gaurish-Dessai Thank you, this is a valid suggestion. We had discussed thsi with our team while we were implementing the Discovery-first approach and here are the few discussion points that came up, based on implementation approach, leading to the current approach.

We found few challenges.

1. In many cases the business user is not aware what they 'want' in AI. For many the SAP solution simply works well for them. Thus this discovery-first process tries to stay consciously away from telling a business user what they need. The 6 steps is an approach to onboard Business Users to the journey and appreciating the value.

2. Taking an entry from ticket analysis, we find people tend to fall into the trap of 'how will I implement it' and the investigation goes away to automation than stay with AI. While Automations bring value for IT by addressing Runners and Repeaters in process and problems, AI addresses value stream. 

3. AI in its current form acts more as a 'helper' and thus we still need 'man-in-between', and not truly autonomous. But with the speed of maturity and training, we have seen R-A-G models where accuracy is sometime better than humans in first pass. This needs not only an AI solution but also change the way AI led automations work.

4. Agree, the idea is to get few POCs (3-5 high value cases we are targeting) done successfully which bring high value, and create the business case for further investment/adaptation. Thus, the Discovery-first approach creates a backlog.

Would like to pursue formalizing the approach. We can further debate on it. Do DM me and we could collaborate in defining the right approach.

 

Best regards

Trijoy Saikia

https://www.linkedin.com/in/trijoysaikia/

entry.title: Re: Bulgaria EUR Transition_Material inventory balance Mi...
entry.content: Hi @AdyashaPatra, sorry for my delayed response, I somehow missed your followup question. You can use multiple approaches when it comes to choosing from the available movement types. If you use movement type 301, a revaluation posting will be posted on the individual goods movement level if the material valuation differs in the sending and receiving plant. If you use 501/502 or 561/562 to independently remove the inventory from the old plant and the goods receipt in the new plant, you can avoid any side effects from direct conversion from BGN to EUR in the goods movement. You have to decide which approach works best for you.

entry.title: Re: End-to-End Message Tracking and Retry Control in SAP Cloud integration
entry.content:
Hi Sushant,

Great explanation.

For Dead Letter Queue processing, I highly recommend using DataStore as your storage and reprocessing medium.

Here are few arguments in favor of DataStore:

First - you can save pretty much anything you want to a DS entry ID. You can even merge multiple attributes into single entry ID if that helps. This makes searching in DataStore monitor super easy. No need to hunt down Message IDs - which is your only filtering option in JMS queue monitor.

Second - you can set up automatic job for reprocessing from DataStore with lower frequency, plus you have the option to run it on demand with custom selection criteria. Want to reprocess all business object IDs (like Sales orders) or Message IDs from Proxy messages? Easy. With JMS, you're stuck with manual handling in the UI.
Sure, you can create a reprocessing iFlow for DLQ JMS as well, but you can't configure retries to run every x hours (limited to start with max 60min -> after exponential max 3h)

Third - JMS queues are really limited (30 by default, max 100), so if you create one DLQ for every JMS sender queue, you're quickly doubling your queue count and running out of resources. You could work around this with some generic-use DLQ queues, but then you need to correlate the generic JMS with specific JMS counterparts using JMS headers. Maybe group several interfaces together and maintain grouped JMS queues instead, but then you do not know what messages belongs to what interfaces... With DataStore - you can create any number of them. Easy maintanance.

Speaking of overcoming JMS limits and adding generalization, unification, and reusability to your landscape - I suggest everyone check out the Pipeline Concept. Even if you don't use it fully, at least look at the design decisions and apply them to your custom templates. For example, there's a really advanced DataStore retry mechanism described here:
https://community.sap.com/t5/integration-blog-posts/process-integration-pipeline-extension-restart-via-data-store/ba-p/14153116 
just discover -> copy -> configure -> deploy.
Works like a charm in my integrations !

All these tips are especially valuable when you're dealing with high-volume processing - manual manipulation in the JMS UI becomes a total nightmare in those scenarios üòû

OK... some might argue that JMS is more performant than DataStore when it comes to high-volume processing. I totally agree, which is why initial buffering always happens on JMS queues - only the DLQ utilizes DataStore. So far I haven't run into any issues with DB locking or releasing.
Second counterargument - DataStores eat into that 32GB tenant limit. Fair point, but again - DataStore is only for reprocessing purposes. If you manage it wisely, this shouldn't be an issue either.

 

br

Mateusz

entry.title: Can the result of CALL TRANSFORMATION be empty?
entry.content:
I'm surprised by this code:

    TRY.
        CALL TRANSFORMATION z_xml_abcd
          SOURCE data = itab
          RESULT XML rv_xml_xstring.

        IF rv_xml_xstring IS INITIAL.
          go_trv_charg_out->log_it_both( |Error : XML generation is impossible| ).
        ENDIF.

      CATCH cx_xslt_runtime_error INTO DATA(lo_ex).
        IF rv_xml_xstring IS INITIAL.
          go_trv_charg_out->log_it_both( |Error : Incompatibility between SAP format and expected |
                                      && |format { lo_ex->s2 }| ).
          gv_error = abap_true.
        ENDIF.
      CATCH cx_transformation_error INTO DATA(lo_error).
        IF rv_xml_xstring IS INITIAL.
          go_trv_charg_out->log_it_both( |ERROR : Incompatibility between SAP format and expected |
                                      && |format { lo_error->get_text( ) }| ).
          gv_error = abap_true.
        ENDIF.
    ENDTRY.

My questions:

  1. Lines 6 to 8: is it possible that without error the XML is empty?
  2. Lines 11 and 16: isn't the generated XML always empty if there's an error, why testing if it's empty?
  3. Line 12: why considering that the attribute S2 is filled in all cases when the exception CX_XSLT_RUNTIME_ERROR is raised, and why not using LO_ERROR->GET_TEXT( ) instead?

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud - API Availability for BP Extens...
entry.content:
Dear @byd,

I apologize but I didn't see your comment earlier. Below are the answers to your questions

Question 1

In this API the item key is AccountingDocument + CompanyCode + FiscalYear + AccountingDocumentItemID
So:

  • YES Accounting Journal Entry / FI Accounting Document number is CORRECT

  • IF Customer Invoice Document Number is only correct if it is the same FI Accounting Document number produced by the posting often yes in FI-based invoicing runs but not the SD Billing Document number

  • NO AR Open Item Document Number isn‚Äôt a separate key here the open item is a line item in the accounting document

Question 2

In Public Cloud the item number is specified as 3 numeric characters for example 001 BUT it‚Äôs mixing between documentation and system. Correct key you will find in Manage Journal Entries app below:

 

 

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/8247ba7cf3344cb6b1092443d10cdebf.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/de7030b74705456997aa9b9b51e66427.html

Question 3

Yes the standard Change pattern in this API is:

  • Put the new value in the ‚Ä¶Change node and

  • Set FieldValueChangeIsRequested to true so SAP actually applies the change

To clear the payment block, you send an initial/blank value for PaymentBlockingReasonCode and FieldValueChangeIsRequested=true

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Statement Level Trigger (SQL Anywhere 17)
entry.content: In the row level trigger, the trigger will not fire for a no-op statement. But a statement level trigger will always fire. The delete is still a no-op since no rows are impacted so there isn't a row for old values. What would the values of OLD be for a non-existent row? There aren't any values so the result set old_rec would have no rows. .

entry.title: Accelerating Your Analytics with Delta Table Replication into SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Related Blogs:
  • Unlocking the True Potential of Data in Files with SAP HANA Database SQL on Files in SAP HANA Cloud
  • Exploring New SQL on Files Use Cases with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 04/2024 and QRC 01/2025

The way we innovate with data is constantly evolving. Since SAP HANA Cloud QRC 04/2024, SAP HANA Cloud has supported read-only access to external Delta Sharing with a dedicated deltasharing adapter, as I introduced in my previous blog. This capability has been instrumental in enabling real-time analytics without physically moving data, unlocking efficiency and delivering faster insights. But what if your business cases demand not just seamless access but also replication of critical datasets into SAP HANA Cloud for deeper analysis, faster queries, or advanced integration?

That‚Äôs where Delta table-to-HANA replication comes in. Starting with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 04/2025, I‚Äôm glad to introduce this new capability, which provides more flexibility to replicate your Delta table directly into the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, empowering your analytics with greater speed, reliability, and robust data management.

In a nutshell, the new Delta table-to-HANA replication has the following capabilities and characteristics:

  • Remote subscription-based initial load and Change Data Capture (CDC) for both file adapter and deltasharing adapter.
  • Support for either chunk-based, user-driven initial load or streamlined, one-step initial load.
  • Support for either user-driven CDC or system-scheduled CDC using the replication job scheduler.
  • Offer both column-wise and row-wise sub-table replication while enabling source-side schema changes (adding columns only).
  • In addition to normal load behavior, UPSERT load behavior with three additional metadata columns: type, last-processed time, and Delta table version.
  • Simplified replication with virtual table toggling and Data Replication UI for the deltasharing adapter in addition to the remote subscription-based replication.

As depicted in the diagram above, the following four combinations can be considered based on the business use case:

  • Chunk-based Initial Load ‚Üí User-driven CDC
  • Chunk-based Initial Load ‚Üí Scheduled CDC
  • One-step Initial Load ‚Üí User-driven CDC
  • One-step initial Load ‚Üí Scheduled CDC

While the one-step initial load is more straightforward and intuitive, chunk-based initial load is useful when the data volume during the initial load is large. With chunk-based initial load, users can have more granular control over the process by splitting the data into multiple chunks and loading them separately. This approach makes the initial load more manageable and easier to handle, especially when dealing with a vast volume of data.

Once the initial load is complete, Change Data Capture (CDC) is required to reflect any data changes on the source side. User-driven CDC allows users to replicate data based on a specific version. This can be particularly useful when the exact Delta table version for replication is known, and there is no need to automatically replicate all the latest changes. Alternatively, scheduled CDC can be used if the use case involves automatic replication at specific time intervals. In this scenario, the default time interval is 3,600 seconds (1 hour), but custom values can be configured as needed.

Now, let‚Äôs dive deeper into the details with some examples. For this, I will use the combination of chunk-based initial load and scheduled CDC with Delta Sharing as the remote source, which is expected to be the most common scenario. However, as explained, other combinations or setups with direct object storage access can also be easily configured by following the linked documentation.

 

Chunk-based Initial Load

As the focus of this blog is Delta table-to-HANA replication, let‚Äôs assume that the remote source to Delta Sharing has already been created and data is accessible via a virtual table. If you‚Äôre not familiar with this, please refer to my previous blogs.

In this example, a virtual table, V_ORDERS, is created by pointing to the remote shared table within Delta Sharing, and it contains 1,500,000 records.

The first step is to create an empty table as the replication target, using the virtual table schema for its definition.

-- create a target table using the virtual table schema for the definition
CREATE TABLE DEMO.R_ORDERS LIKE DEMO.V_ORDERS;

With this, a remote subscription can now be created as shown below.

-- create a remote subscription
CREATE REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION ON DEMO.V_ORDERS TARGET TABLE DEMO.R_ORDERS;

Here, if needed, as briefly mentioned, column-wise or row-wise sub-table replication can be configured by using a subquery with the CREATE REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION ... ON ... AS <subquery> TARGET TABLE ...;. Additionally, enabling source-side schema changes (adding columns only) or defining load behaviors can also be done together.

Once a remote subscription is created, we now have two options: the chunk-based initial load and the one-step initial load. In this example, I will use the chunk-based initial load.

-- prepare the initial load by defining the chunk size
ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION INITIAL LOAD PREPARE CHUNK SIZE 10;

-- retrieve the chunk information
SELECT * FROM M_REMOTE_SUBSCRIPTION_INITIAL_LOADS;

In this example, I set the chunk size to 10, which is 10 MiB. However, it is also possible not to define the chunk size here, as in the statement ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION INITIAL LOAD PREPARE;. If the chunk size is not specified, the default size of 100 MiB will be used.

If I check the chunk information in the M_REMOTE_SUBSCRIPTION_INITIAL_LOADS monitoring view, the result is as follows.

As you can see, three chunks with CHUNK_IDs 1, 2, and 3 are defined, and each chunk contains approximately 430,000 to 537,000 records, respectively. The EXECUTION_STATUS column indicates whether a chunk has been loaded or not. Since I haven‚Äôt loaded any of them yet, all of them show as PREPARED.

Now, let me load chunks 1 and 2 first.

-- load chunks 1 and 2
ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION INITIAL LOAD EXECUTE CHUNK 1, 2;

-- retrieve the chunk information
SELECT * FROM M_REMOTE_SUBSCRIPTION_INITIAL_LOADS;

Since only chunks 1 and 2 are loaded, the EXECUTION_STATUS in the monitoring view now shows LOADED for those two chunks, as shown below.

In this way, each chunk can be loaded as desired, and its status can be monitored. With that, let me load the last chunk and finalize the initial load.

-- load the chunk 3
ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION INITIAL LOAD EXECUTE CHUNK 3;

-- finalize the initial load
ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION INITIAL LOAD FINALIZE;

All chunks must be marked as LOADED in EXECUTION_STATUS to finalize the initial load. FINALIZE will also delete all corresponding rows in the M_REMOTE_SUBSCRIPTION_INITIAL_LOADS monitoring view. Now, I can see that all data has been loaded into the R_ORDERS table.

Please refer to the links below for further details on the initial load.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database SQL on Files Guide: Configuring Delta Table Replication
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database SQL on Files Guide: Performing an Initial Load

 

Scheduled CDC

Once the initial load is finalized, CDC can be achieved in two ways: user-driven CDC or scheduled CDC. In this example, I will use the scheduled CDC.

-- scheduled CDC with a 30-minute interval (1,800 seconds)
ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION DISTRIBUTE INTERVAL 1800;

-- retrieve the replication jobs
SELECT * FROM M_REMOTE_REPLICATION_JOBS;

If the interval is not specified, the default time interval of 3,600 seconds (1 hour) will be used. In this example, completed and planned replication jobs can be retrieved via the M_REMOTE_REPLICATION_JOBS monitoring view.

As shown above, the first CDC job was planned for 05:35:19 and completed successfully. The next job is planned for 06:05:19, which is 30 minutes later, as expected. One important note is that, to execute the DISTRIBUTE, the enableChangeDataFeed property must be set on the source Delta table.

Please refer to the links below for further details on the CDC.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database SQL on Files Guide: Performing System-scheduled CDC Replication
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database SQL on Files Guide: Performing User-driven CDC Replication

 

Deactivate and Drop Remote Subscription

If needed, the configured remote subscription can be deactivated and dropped using the statements below.

-- deactivate the remote subscription
ALTER REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION RESET;

-- drop the remote subscription 
DROP REMOTE SUBSCRIPTION DEMO.DELTA_SUBSCRIPTION;

Deactivating the remote subscription will cancel all planned replication jobs from the scheduled CDC. However, since the remote subscription itself remains active, you can start again from the initial load step. Please note that the replica table, R_ORDERS in this example, will still contain replicated data. Therefore, truncating the replica table is required to start over.

Dropping the remote subscription will delete all entries, including the monitoring views. However, the replica table, R_ORDERS in this example, will remain with the replicated data and can be used as a normal table.

Please refer to the links below for further details on the deactivation and drop.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database SQL on Files Guide: Configuring Delta Table Replication

 

Other Interfaces

The remote subscription-based initial load and CDC combination mentioned above is the primary interface used for Delta table-to-HANA replication. However, there are a couple of other interfaces with simplified steps.

The first option involves toggling between federation and replication for the virtual table. Toggling has been supported previously, but only with snapshot replication. Starting with QRC 04/2025, toggling now supports real-time replication as well, as shown below.

-- add a system-owned replica to a virtual table with a 30-minute interval
ALTER VIRTUAL TABLE V_ORDERS ADD SHARED REPLICA REFRESH INTERVAL 1800;

-- delete a replica
ALTER VIRTUAL TABLE V_ORDERS DROP REPLICA;

In this approach, any queries on the virtual table will retrieve data from the replica instead of fetching data on-the-fly from the remote table. Since this is a simplified one-step process designed to offer better performance while maintaining the target object as a virtual table, it does not support granular controls such as chunk-based initial load or sub-table replication. The above example illustrates a system-owned replica, but a user-owned replica is also supported. Here, as with the remote subscription-based approach, if REFRESH INTERVAL is not specified, the default time interval of 3,600 seconds (1 hour) will be used.

Please refer to the links below for further details on the toggling.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database SQL on Files Guide: Toggling Between Virtual Tables and Replica Tables

Another interface involves using the SAP HANA Cloud Central UI. In SAP HANA Cloud Central, Data Replication has been utilized for hybrid scenarios, such as replicating data from SAP HANA Platform 2.0 to SAP HANA Cloud. Starting with QRC 04/2025, Data Replication now also supports replicating data from Delta Sharing to SAP HANA Cloud.

In this UI, either an existing remote source for Delta Sharing can be used or a new remote source can be created while configuring replication.

Unlike other interfaces, it only supports the Delta Sharing remote source, which is based on the deltasharing adapter.

As shown above, once the data objects to be replicated are selected, the replication schedule can be set to either 'Real Time', which uses scheduled CDC, or 'None', which performs only a one-time initial load. For 'Real Time', as explained above, the enableChangeDataFeed property must be set on the source Delta table.

Once confirmed, the replication status can now be monitored. For example, 'Completed', which means the one-time initial load is finished, or 'Loading...', which indicates that scheduled CDC is being activated.

Similar to toggling, as it is a simplified approach, it does not support granular controls such as chunk-based initial load, sub-table replication, or setting time intervals. However, like existing SAP HANA Platform 2.0-to-SAP HANA Cloud hybrid scenarios, it provides a way to configure the replication schedule, storage type, and a consolidated view of all replication tasks. Please refer to the links below for further details on using the SAP HANA Cloud Central UI.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Data Replication in SAP HANA Cloud Central

 

Conclusion

To wrap things up, the Delta table replication capability introduced with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 04/2025 represents a transformative step forward in data integration and analytics. This advanced functionality provides businesses with the flexibility to address diverse use cases, enabling deeper insights and streamlined data management. Whether the focus is on real-time updates or managing large-scale initial data loads, these features deliver tailored solutions designed to optimize performance and efficiency. With SAP HANA Cloud at the forefront of innovation, the possibilities for unlocking the true power of your data are boundless. Be sure to explore these exciting capabilities to elevate your enterprise to the next level.

entry.title: R√ºckblick und Ausblick: Die SAP Change und Training Community feiert ein erfolgreiches Jahr
entry.content:
Highlights eines bewegten Jahres

SAP Training und Adoption Forum

Das SAP Training und Adoption Forum im Juni war zweifellos ein H√∂hepunkt. Mit dem Motto "Activate Human Superpowers" traf die Veranstaltung einen Nerv: 120 Teilnehmende am Vorabend, 150 am Veranstaltungstag und 200 online ‚Äì die Location platzte erfreulicherweise aus allen N√§hten. Besonders die neuen Formate wie Promptathon, ein KI Use Case Exploration Workshop sowie KI-Dokumentation schufen Experimentierr√§ume, die zum Lernen und Ausprobieren einluden.

Besonders bemerkenswert war die nachhaltige Wirkung: Zahlreiche Social-Media-Posts zeigten, wie das Motto und die positive Stimmung die Teilnehmenden inspirierte und wie wichtig die nachhaltige Verankerung von Change und Training in Organisationen ist. Die Inhalte der Veranstaltung sind √ºber die Zusammenfassung im Blog (LINK)  in der SAP Community zug√§nglich, inklusive der KI Dokumentation (LINK).

SAP Change und Training Kaffee-Ecke und Community

Die monatliche Kaffeeecke hat sich nach drei bis vier Jahren als verl√§ssliches Austauschformat etabliert. Die konstante, vertrauensvolle Zusammenarbeit zeigt sich nicht nur im numerischen Wachstum, sondern vor allem in der Qualit√§t der Diskussionen. Jeden dritten Donnerstag im Monat treffen sich Change- und Learning-Profis, um Erfahrungen zu teilen ‚Äì von Fallstudien wie der S/4HANA-Transformation bei Heidelberg Materials bis zu Deep Dives in spezifische Themen wie Key-User-Netzwerke. Die LinkedIn-Community (LINK) legte zwischen Juni und Dezember noch einmal einen deutlichen Wachstumsschub hin. In der SAP Community Gruppen wurden auch 2025 wieder eifrig Blogs geschrieben: 30 Blogs mit √ºber 20.000 Views zeigen, da√ü es Bedarf an unseren Themen gibt.

Peer Learning zu OCM in SAP Projekten

Mit der Learning Circle Experience wurde ein weiteres Format aufgesetzt: 12 Wochen selbstgesteuertes Peer-Learning zum Thema "OCM in SAP-Projekten" auf Basis des LernOS Leitfadens zu Changemanagement. Von 219 Registrierungen hielt etwa die H√§lfte bis zum Ende durch ‚Äì ein erfreuliches Ergebnis f√ºr ein Format, das w√∂chentlich 2 Stunden Engagement √ºber drei Monate in Anspruch nimmt.

Eine zentrale Erkenntnis: Die eigentliche Lernerfahrung liegt nicht im Lesen des Leitfadens, sondern in der Reflexion und im Austausch der Perspektiven und jeweiligen Erfahrungen. Das Peer-Learning funktioniert wunderbar auch mit gemischten Vorkenntnissen. Change-Interessierte und Change-Profis lernten voneinander auf Augenh√∂he. Der Leitfaden kann auch firmenintern f√ºr Workshops, Lernreisen im Peer-Learning Format oder zur Bef√§higung in Projekten genutzt werden. Anbei der Link zur Retrospektive.

EducationNewscast zu spannenden und relevanten Themen

Der Community-Podcast entwickelte sich kontinuierlich weiter ‚Äì trotz eines Security Hacks, der die Plattform auf openSAP beeintr√§chtigte. Mit etwa 3.000 bis 4.000 Streams monatlich zeigt das Format: Menschen sch√§tzen den Blick in die Praxis und in neue Themen.

Inhalte zu AI-Adoption,  verschiedene Learning und Change Fallstudien und auch ungew√∂hnliche Perspektiven wie etwa eine Polizistin als SAP S/4HANA-Projektleiterin oder ein AI-Recruiting-Startup bringen Vielfalt und immer wieder neue Lernmomente in den Change- und Learning-Diskurs. Die SAP Themen reichten von SAP AI Agents √ºber WalkMe und die SAP Integrated Toolchain bis hin zu Zertifizierung und Learning. Den EducationNewsCast Podcast findet ihr  auf Spotify  oder Apple Podcasts

KI-KnowHow Aufbau im SAP Kontext: Motivation trifft auf Umsetzungsl√ºcke 

Eine kuratierte Sammlung etwa 20 - 30 SAP-Lerninhalten zum Thema KI, sortiert nach Rollen, sowie ein Self-Assessment zur KI-Kompetenz offenbarten ein interessantes Muster: Die Motivation, sich mit KI zu besch√§ftigen, ist enorm hoch. Die Kriterien des Assessments orientierten sich an Change-Dimensionen: Awareness, Motivation, Knowledge and Implementation, √§hnlich dem ADKAR-Modell. Doch bei der tats√§chlichen Umsetzung hapert es noch erheblich. Das Wissen und die Implementation zeigen deutliche L√ºcken. Doch alleine Wissen aufbauen reicht nicht, schnell ins Tun kommen ist entscheidend: Formate wie Hackathons, Promptathons oder Use-Case-Explorationen k√∂nnen hier die Br√ºcke schlagen. Detail k√∂nnt ihr in folgenden Blogs nachlesen:
Blog: SAP AI Training und SAP AI Skills Self-Assessment
Blog: Auswertung des AI Self Assessments

Learnings aus der Community: Was 2025 pr√§gte

Die Mentimeter-Umfrage zu den Aha-Momenten 2025 brachte eine F√ºlle an Erkenntnissen: Von "Kommunikation ist das A und O" wie "KI und ihre Grenzen" sowie der Erkenntnis, dass S/4HANA-Transformationen als ganzheitliches Unternehmensprojekt zu begreifen sind,. Wie eine Teilnehmerin es treffend formulierte: "Fr√ºher haben wir ein neues SAP bekommen und da wurde nur ein bisschen anders geklickt. Heute ist der Change so viel gr√∂√üer. Es sind die Prozesse, die sich √§ndern, die Organisation, die Technik und nat√ºrlich der Mensch."

Ein weiteres zentrales Thema wurde auf den Punkt gebracht: Change Fatigue. Microsoft 365 mit Copilot, S/4HANA-Transformationen, Rise auf die Cloud, dazu Joule ‚Äì die Endanwender sind gefordert, aber auch die Berater selbst. "Viele Berater kennen dieses AI Consulting noch gar nicht. Das wird auch noch mal intern zu einer Herausforderung", so die Beobachtung eines Teilnehmers. Die Diskussion m√ºndete in der Frage: Wie ver√§ndern KI und Agenten die Beratung selbst? Ein Thema, das definitiv auf die Agenda f√ºr 2026 geh√∂rt.

Weitere zentrale Erkenntnisse: Change Management wird immer wichtiger, jedoch wollen Unternehmen leider zu wenig investieren. Umso wichtiger ist gemeinsame Lobbyarbeit f√ºr das Thema und das Schaffen von Sensibilit√§t. Peer Learning wurde als wertvolles Format gelobt, User Communities als hilfreich erkannt, und die Bedeutung von Live-Veranstaltungen betont. Kritisch angemerkt wurde, dass es immer noch Projektmanager gibt, die Change Management nicht im Fokus haben.

Vors√§tze f√ºr 2026: Zwischen Resilienz und Deep Learning

Bei den Vors√§tzen f√ºr das neue Jahr zeigt sich eine gesunde Mischung aus fachlichen und pers√∂nlichen Zielen. Change Energy, Resilienz und mehr Userorientierung stehen neben dem Wunsch nach mehr Bewegung und Freude. Die Forderung nach transformationaler F√ºhrung traf auf die realistische Einsch√§tzung: "Es sind die Babyboomer, die jetzt noch √ºberall in den F√ºhrungsetagen sitzen. In ein paar Jahren sind sie alle weg und dann wird es wieder anders." Deep Learning im Bereich KI, ein Lernender bleiben und SAP-Speak besser erkl√§ren ‚Äì die Bandbreite zeigt, wo die Community steht.

Change-Mottos f√ºr 2026: Von "Balance, Breath und Ballon" bis "Never give up"

Die Frage nach einem Change-Motto f√ºr 2026 brachte kreative und inspirierende Vorschl√§ge hervor. "Ride the Change" kam ebenso wie "Change up your life", "Mensch und KI in Symbiose" oder "Start zu neuen Ufern". Besonders originell: "Balance, Breath und Ballon" ‚Äì ein Versuchsballon als Metapher f√ºr etwas Au√üergew√∂hnliches, das Neugier weckt und ins Gespr√§ch bringt. "If you fail to prepare, you prepare to fail" erinnerte an die Bedeutung guter Vorbereitung, w√§hrend "Navigating SAP Empowering People" die Verbindung von Technologie und Mensch betonte. Auch etwas martialische Vorschl√§ge wie "Kill change, start future" zeigten: Manchmal muss man alte Z√∂pfe abschneiden. Auch ‚ÄûMut zur L√ºcke‚Äú ist in der heutigen Zeit unverzichtbar ‚Äì die Frage ist nur, welche L√ºcke man l√§sst.

Ermutigungen f√ºr die Community: Together we can

Die Kudos-Runde am Ende der Session brachte wertvolle Empfehlungen f√ºr Community-Mitglieder. "Together we can" bringt den Gemeinschaftsgedanken auf den Punkt. "Deine Beteiligung macht einen Unterschied", "Jeder Change beginnt mit dem ersten Schritt" und "Never give up" waren ebenso zu h√∂ren wie der pragmatische Rat: "Networking betreiben und einfach mal fragen. Wir sitzen alle mit den gleichen Problemen im selben Boot und k√∂nnen uns super erg√§nzen √ºber die Unternehmen hinweg."

Dar√ºber hinaus wurde erw√§hnt, dass die Trennung zwischen der Person und der Rolle als Change-Verantwortliche viel Frust verhindern kann. Lessons Learned aus vergangenen Projekten sollten genutzt werden, um Change zu platzieren. Ein Teilnehmer mahnte: "Man untersch√§tzt immer wieder die Transformationsprojekte und denkt, dass man mit dem gleichen Vorgehen das auch wieder umsetzen kann. Das scheitert immer wieder. Deshalb: Lessons Learned nutzen und den Menschen wirklich ins Zentrum stellen."

Ausblick 2026: Von Walk Me bis zur moderierten Expertenrunde

Das neue Jahr startet gleich im Januar mit einem Walk-Me-Webinar zur neuen Learning-L√∂sung ‚ÄûWalkMe Learning Arc‚Äú (21. Januar, Anmeldung) und einer Kaffeeecke zum Thema " Von Werkzeugen zu Wegweisern: MHPs Erfolgsmodell in der Berater:innen-Ausbildung" (22. Januar, Anmeldung). Im Februar folgt ein Deep Dive zu Cultural Readiness und Change Impact Analyse im Kontext der SAP S/4HANA-Transformation.

F√ºr Enable-Now-Kunden gibt es zudem Round Tables zur Transition zu Walk Me (Zur Anmeldung geht es hier).

Die Themensammlung f√ºr 2026 zeigt die Bandbreite der Interessen: KI-Adoption, Walk Me, Integrated Tool Chain stehen fest. Dar√ºber hinaus wurden Erfolgsbedingungen f√ºr Change Management (oder umgekehrt: was passiert, wenn man es nicht macht), SAP Fiori Apps mit Key-User-Erweiterbarkeit, der Wandel in der IT durch Low-Code-Ans√§tze und eine moderierte Expertenrunde mit Change-Experten aus Praxis und Wissenschaft gew√ºnscht. Die Frage nach aktueller Forschung zu Change bleibt spannend ‚Äì hier gibt es noch Luft nach oben.

KI-Tools f√ºr die Community: Von Notebook LM bis zum Promptathon

Ein weiterer Impuls kam aus der Runde: In einem informellen Netzwerk von zehn erfahrenen Changern werden interessante Artikel und Links gesammelt und mit Notebook LM ein Podcast erstellt. Der Vorteil: Es ist attraktiver als eine Ablage mit Artikeln, die man mal lesen w√ºrde, wenn man Zeit h√§tte. √Ñhnlich k√∂nnen wir das auch sicher nutzen, wir schauen uns das gemeinsam mal an n√§chstes Jahr.

Von der Community wurde der Wunsch ge√§ussert, KI in die Community zu bringen. Die Diskussion f√ºhrte zu konkreten √úberlegungen: Ein Promptathon mit Change-Fokus, der co-kreativ etwas f√ºr die Community entwickelt, oder die Nutzung von Notebook LM f√ºr Kaffee-Ecke-Summaries und Change-Themen wie Kommunikation oder Enablement. Die Idee eines KI-Tools f√ºr die Community, das Wissen b√ºndelt und zug√§nglich macht ‚Äì eine Mischung aus GPT und Wiki ‚Äì, stie√ü auf gro√ües Interesse.

Ein Jahr voller spannender Themen ‚Äì und noch mehr stehen bevor

In diesem Sinne: Ein wundersch√∂nes Weihnachtsfest, Zeit zum Durchatmen (ohne E-Mails!) und einen guten Start in ein wahrscheinlich sehr changereiches Jahr 2026 ‚Äì f√ºr alle Beteiligten.

Resources: A, B, C

Orders: O1, O2, O3, O4 (all orders are initially planned on resource A before the heuristic run.)

Expected result: 

Res. A: O1, O2 >> capacity fully utilized, switch on res. B

Res. B: O3, O4

Res. C: empy (no remaining orders)

Best regards

Liana

entry.title: Mobile Services - Replacing Credential Type from Instance-Secret to Binding-Secret
entry.content:
Guide for Mobile Services Cockpit

This guide provides further details to SAP Note 3697481. Follow the step-by-step instructions for replacing credential types from instance-secret to binding-secret via Mobile Services Cockpit. This process is essential for maintaining compatibility with updated security requirements in SAP BTP environments.

Overview

When XSUAA service instances use the unsupported instance-secret credential type, they need to be updated to use binding-secret instead. This process involves identifying affected instances, deleting the problematic service keys, and restoring the mobile service instances through the Mobile Services Cockpit.

High-Level Flow

  1. Manually identify XSUAA instances with unsupported credential type
  2. Delete affected service key
  3. Restore mobile service instance via Mobile Services Cockpit

Step 1: Manually Identify XSUAA Instances with Unsupported Credential Type

1.1 Access BTP Cockpit

  • Log in to the BTP Cockpit on your subscriber subaccount
  • Navigate to the "Service Instances" section by going to Services ‚Üí Instances

1.2 Filter for Authorization & Trust Management Services

  • Select "Authorization & Trust Management" from the service type filter to display only XSUAA instances

1.3 Inspect Service Keys

  • Click on the relevant XSUAA service instance to open its detail view
  • Navigate to the "Service Keys" section within the service detail view
  • Examine the credential type for each service key

1.4 Identify Problematic Keys

  • Look for service keys with credential type "instance-secret"
  • These service keys need to be deleted and recreated

Note: Service keys with instance-secret credential type are no longer supported and must be replaced with binding-secret type.

Step 2: Delete Affected Service Key

2.1 Navigate to Service Keys Section

  • In the XSUAA service detail view, ensure you're in the "Service Keys" section
  • Locate the service key with the "instance-secret" credential type

2.2 Delete the Service Key

  • Select the service key with the "instance-secret" credential type
  • Click on the "Delete" button to remove the affected service key

 

2.3 Confirm Deletion

  • Confirm the deletion when prompted by the system
  • Wait for the deletion process to complete

 

Important: This will cause a temporary state change to "INCONSISTENT" for the mobile service instance until the application is restored in the next step.

Step 3: Restore Mobile Service Instance via Mobile Services Cockpit

3.1 Access Mobile Services Cockpit

  • Log in to the Mobile Services Cockpit
  • Navigate to the Native/MDK mobile apps list view by going to Mobile Applications ‚Üí Native/MDK

 

3.2 Trigger Consistency Check

  • In the browser URL bar, replace the /index.html#/page.apps.native part with /apps
  • This action triggers a consistency check of the mobile services instances in your space

 

 

 

3.3 Return to Native/MDK Apps View

  • Navigate back to the Native/MDK mobile apps list view
  • Use the browser's back button or navigate via Mobile Applications ‚Üí Native/MDK

 

3.4 Locate Inconsistent Instances

  • Manually refresh the list view (using browser refresh or the refresh button)
  • Continue refreshing until affected instances show "INCONSISTENT" state
  • Look for mobile service instances that have changed to this state

 

3.5 Open Instance Detail View

  • Select the affected mobile service instance with the "INCONSISTENT" state
  • Click on the instance to open its detail view

3.6 Restore the Instance

  • In the instance detail view, locate and click the "Restore" button
  • This will initiate the restoration process for the mobile service instance

 

3.7 Verify Restoration

  • Refresh the detail view after a few moments
  • Confirm that the state has changed back to "RUNNING"
  • The instance should now be using the correct binding-secret credential type

Important Notes

  • Repeat the above steps for each affected XSUAA service key identified in Step 1
  • The restoration process may take several minutes to complete
  • Monitor the instance status carefully to ensure successful restoration
  • If an instance remains in "INCONSISTENT" state for an extended period, contact support

Summary

This process ensures that your mobile service instances use the supported binding-secret credential type instead of the deprecated instance-secret type. The temporary inconsistent state is expected and resolved through the restoration process in the Mobile Services Cockpit.

For additional support or questions regarding this process, consult your SAP BTP administrator or contact SAP Support.

entry.title: Adding Attachments from AL11 to ME22n using custom program
entry.content:
Greetings,

I'm Trying to attach the attachments(PDF's) from AL11 directory to ME22n Transaction, I'm able to attach the file to PO but I cannot open that. below code is used in my program
FORM attach_file_to_po  USING iv_ebeln       TYPE ebeln
                              iv_full_path   TYPE string
                              iv_filename    "type epsfilnam""pfeflname
                       CHANGING cv_error_msg TYPE string.

  DATA: lv_objkey       TYPE sibflporb-instid,
        ls_borident     TYPE borident,
        ls_attachment   TYPE borident,
        lv_doc_type     TYPE soodk-objtp, "so_obj_tp,
        ls_folder_id    TYPE soodk,
        ls_sofm1        TYPE sofm1,
        ls_sood1        TYPE sood1,
        ls_document     TYPE sood4,
        lt_content_bin  TYPE solix_tab,
        lt_content_soli TYPE soli_tab,
        lt_content      TYPE soli_tab, "TABLE OF SOLI, " solix_tab,
        ls_content      TYPE soli, "solix,
        lv_size         TYPE i,
        lv_file_size    TYPE i,
        lt_objhead      TYPE soli_tab,
        ls_objhead      TYPE soli,
        lv_ep_note      TYPE borident,
        lv_object_id    TYPE soodk,    "sofolenti1-object_id,
        lt_hex_content  TYPE solix_tab,
        lv_binfilesize  TYPE i,
        lv_buffer       TYPE xstring,
        ls_solix        TYPE solix,
        ls_soli         TYPE soli,
*        lv_binfilesize  TYPE i,
        lv_objkey_msg   TYPE sibflporb-instid,
        lv_xstring      TYPE xstring,
        lv_file         TYPE string,
        lt_binary       TYPE TABLE OF x255,
        ls_binary       TYPE x255,
        lt_objcont      TYPE soli_tab,
        ls_objcont      TYPE soli.

  DATA: lv_hd_display TYPE sood2.

  " Build object key for PO
  lv_objkey = iv_ebeln.
  CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERSION_EXIT_ALPHA_INPUT'
    EXPORTING
      input  = lv_objkey
    IMPORTING
      output = lv_objkey.
  " Read file from application server
  PERFORM read_file_from_server USING iv_full_path
                                CHANGING lt_content_bin
                                         lv_binfilesize
                                         cv_error_msg.

  IF cv_error_msg IS NOT INITIAL.
    RETURN.
  ENDIF.
  lv_file = iv_full_path.
CALL FUNCTION 'SO_SOLIXTAB_TO_SOLITAB'
  EXPORTING
    ip_solixtab       = lt_content_bin
 IMPORTING
   EP_SOLITAB        = lt_objcont.
 " Determine document type based on extension
  IF iv_filename CS '.pdf' OR iv_filename CS '.PDF'.
    lv_doc_type = 'PDF'.
  ELSEIF iv_filename CS '.xls' OR iv_filename CS '.xlsx' OR
         iv_filename CS '.XLS' OR iv_filename CS '.XLSX'.
    lv_doc_type = 'XLS'.
  ELSEIF iv_filename CS '.doc' OR iv_filename CS '.docx' OR
         iv_filename CS '.DOC' OR iv_filename CS '.DOCX'.
    lv_doc_type = 'DOC'.
  ELSEIF iv_filename CS '.txt' OR iv_filename CS '.TXT'.
    lv_doc_type = 'RAW'.
  ELSE.
    lv_doc_type = 'EXT'.
  ENDIF.

  " Prepare OBJHEAD table - like dialog
  CLEAR ls_objhead.
  CONCATENATE '&SO_FILENAME=' iv_filename INTO ls_objhead-line.
  APPEND ls_objhead TO lt_objhead.

 CLEAR ls_objhead.
  ls_objhead-line = '&SO_FORMAT=BIN'.
  APPEND ls_objhead TO lt_objhead.
  CALL FUNCTION 'SO_FOLDER_ROOT_ID_GET'
    EXPORTING
      region                = 'B'
    IMPORTING
      folder_id             = ls_folder_id
    EXCEPTIONS
      communication_failure = 1
      owner_not_exist       = 2
      system_failure        = 3
      x_error               = 4.
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    ls_folder_id-objtp = 'FOL'.
    ls_folder_id-objyr = '99'.
    ls_folder_id-objno = space.
  ENDIF.

  ls_sood1-file_ext = 'PDF'. "lv_doc_type."'PDF'.
  ls_sood1-extct    = 'K'.
  ls_sood1-objdes   = iv_filename.
  ls_sood1-objpri   = '5'.
  ls_sood1-objla    = sy-langu.
  ls_sood1-objlen   = lv_binfilesize.
  " Create attachment using SO_OBJECT_INSERT
  CALL FUNCTION 'SO_OBJECT_INSERT'
    EXPORTING
      folder_id                  = ls_folder_id "'FOL01'
      object_type                = lv_doc_type
      object_fl_change           = ls_sofm1
      object_hd_change           = ls_sood1
    IMPORTING
      object_id                  = lv_object_id
    TABLES
*     objcont                    = lt_content
      objcont                    = lt_objcont "lt_content_soli
      objhead                    = lt_objhead
    EXCEPTIONS
      active_user_not_exist      = 1
      communication_failure      = 2
      component_not_available    = 3
      folder_not_exist           = 4
      folder_no_authorization    = 5
      object_type_not_exist      = 6
      operation_no_authorization = 7
      owner_not_exist            = 8
      parameter_error            = 9
      substitute_not_active      = 10
      substitute_not_defined     = 11
      system_failure             = 12
      x_error                    = 13
      OTHERS                     = 14.
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    cv_error_msg = 'Error creating attachment object'.
    RETURN.
  ENDIF.

  DATA lt_tbl1024 TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF tbl1024.
  DATA lv_xstr TYPE xstring.

  lv_objkey = iv_ebeln.

  CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERSION_EXIT_ALPHA_OUTPUT'
    EXPORTING
      input  = lv_objkey
    IMPORTING
      output = lv_objkey.


  ls_borident-objkey = iv_ebeln.
  ls_borident-objtype = 'BUS2012'.

  ls_document-foltp = ls_folder_id-objtp.
  ls_document-folyr = ls_folder_id-objyr.
  ls_document-folno = ls_folder_id-objno.
*  ls_document-objtp = lv_object_id-objtp.
  ls_document-objtp = attach_id-objtp.
*  ls_document-objyr = lv_object_id-objyr.
  ls_document-objyr = attach_id-objyr.
*  ls_document-objno = lv_object_id-objno.
  ls_document-objno = attach_id-objno.

  ls_attachment-objkey = ls_document(34).
  ls_attachment-objtype = 'MESSAGE'.

  " Link attachment to PO using BINARY_RELATION_CREATE_COMMIT
  CALL FUNCTION 'BINARY_RELATION_CREATE_COMMIT'
    EXPORTING
      obj_rolea    = ls_borident
      obj_roleb    = ls_attachment
      relationtype = 'ATTA'
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS       = 1.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    cv_error_msg = 'Error linking attachment to PO'.
    RETURN.
  ENDIF.

  COMMIT WORK.

Endform.

entry.title: 1H 2026 SuccessFactors Onboarding Enhancement: Smarter, More Flexible Form I-9 Reverification
entry.content:
Staying compliant with Form I-9 requirements is critical‚Äîand we‚Äôre making it easier than ever. Upcoming enhancements to the SuccessFactors Onboarding application introduce greater visibility, flexibility, and reporting capabilities for Form I-9 Reverification (Supplement B).

Originally, we had announced that the functionality to manually trigger Form I-9 Reverification activities from Manage Data will deprecate in the upcoming 1H 2026 Release; we've extended this to 2H 2026 Release (November 2026) to introduce a phase of time where customers can use the new functionality, but also have the reliability of the old solution/workaround.

Clearer Visibility Where You Need It Most

Form I-9 Reverification and Supplement B details will now be displayed directly on the New Hire Details page, part of the Onboarding Dashboard. This brings critical employment eligibility information into a single, easy-to-access location, reducing the need to navigate multiple areas of the application. The usual controls for this activity will be present now in the New Hire Details page, not just the Home Page Cards or the Manage Data area.

The Form I-9 Reverification / Supplement B Task will now appear on the New Hire Details page in applicable scenarios, similar to Onboarding 1.0's Show All I-9 Reverifications.

A New Workflow for Citizenship Status Changes

We‚Äôre introducing a new, streamlined workflow that automatically supports scenarios where a New Hire‚Äôs Citizenship Status changes. This ensures the correct I-9 Reverification steps are triggered (or not triggered) at the right time, helping organizations remain compliant without manual intervention. This also brings Onboarding further up to parity with functions Onboarding 1.0 has.

Configurable Reverification Timeframes

Every organization‚Äôs compliance needs are different. To support that, customers will now be able to configure when I-9 Reverification/Supplement B activities are triggered. Supported timeframes include: 30, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240, or 540 days.

This flexibility allows you to align reverification timing with internal policies and workforce needs.

Improved Reporting and Task Visibility

We‚Äôre also working on additional enhancements to further improve oversight and transparency:

  • Reportable I-9 Reverification Object
    Today, I-9 Reverification data can only be accessed through the I-9 Audit Trail. We plan to make the I-9 Reverification object directly reportable, enabling simpler, more targeted reporting.

  • Dedicated Reverification Activity Card
    A new, separate card for I-9 Reverification/Supplement B activities will make it easier for users to identify and manage these tasks without confusion.

These improvements are designed to reduce administrative effort, improve compliance confidence, and give customers more control over how I-9 Reverification is managed in SuccessFactors Onboarding. We look forward to delivering these updates and continuing to enhance your onboarding experience.

entry.title: Re: Update asset useful life
entry.content:
Hello @wonken 

Below is the complete explanation covering issue, reason, correct approach, checks, and alternatives.

 

SectionItemDetails
ScenarioAsset capitalizationCapitalized in FY 2024
 Original useful life10 years
 Required changeUseful life to end in Jun-2026
 Effective date1-Apr-25
ErrorError messageE669 ‚Äì Fiscal year 2024 is already closed in financial accounting
Root CauseWhy error occursSAP tries to recalculate depreciation from capitalization year (2024)
 System behaviorUseful life change impacts closed fiscal year
 FI statusFY 2024 closed in FI / FI-AA
Key ConceptUseful life change typeTime-dependent change
 SAP requirementChange must be effective from a future open date
Correct Method (Recommended)TransactionAS02 ‚Äì Change Asset
 Tab to useTime-Dependent tab
 Change date1-Apr-25
 Field to updateUseful life (only in time-dependent data)
 General tabDo NOT change useful life here
Expected System Result2024 depreciationRemains unchanged
 2025 onwardDepreciation recalculated from Apr-2025 to Jun-2026
 Error resolutionE669 eliminated
Post Change ActivityDepreciation runExecute AFAB
 Posting periodRun for 2025 periods only
System Checks (If Error Persists)FI-AA fiscal yearOAYZ ‚Äì FY 2025 must be open
 Posting periodsOB52 ‚Äì 2025 asset periods open
 Depreciation areaChange allowed for relevant depreciation area
Alternative Option (Not Preferred)ActionReopen FY 2024
 TransactionsOB52 + OAYZ
 RiskImpacts closed financial year
 Recommendation‚ùå Avoid in production
Best PracticeSAP standardAlways use time-dependent changes
 Audit complianceNo changes to closed FY
 Financial accuracyCorrect depreciation from effective date

entry.title: Re: Statement Level Trigger (SQL Anywhere 17)
entry.content:
> even if the statement was tried unsucessfully, i.e. no-op delete-statement
Well, an UPDATE or DELETE statement which does not affect any row is still successful. I have no clue how you could "log" a statement that doesn't affect rows - other by request-level-logging, but that might be overkill here...
If you can force users to issue a stored procedure instead of a pure DELETE, you could of course add logic to trace the procedure call (and possible parameters), even if no rows are affected.

entry.title: Re: How to Monitor Missing Bank Statements in SAP
entry.content:
Hello @R_Pooja ,

Below is the complete explanation covering issue, reason, correct approach, checks, and alternatives.

 

TopicDetails
Issue ObservedBank statements were not received in SAP for several days due to a technical issue, with no prior notification.
SAP Standard CapabilitySAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition does not provide a standard automatic alert when a bank statement file is missing.
Manual Monitoring (Fiori Apps)Treasury teams must manually monitor statement receipt using Monitor Bank Statements and Manage Bank Statements Fiori apps.
Statement Date Gap CheckA common control is to check for missing statement dates (expected daily statements per bank account). Gaps indicate non-receipt.
Job MonitoringApplication Job Monitoring can send email alerts if the bank statement import job fails, but it cannot detect missing files when the job runs successfully.
Bank Connectivity MonitoringManage Bank Connectivity / MBC shows technical connection status but does not confirm whether a statement was actually received.
Cash Flow ReviewCash Flow Analyzer can indirectly highlight missing statements if expected cash movements are not reflected.
Proactive Alerting (Recommended)SAP BTP Alert Notification Service can be configured to trigger alerts if no bank statement is received within a defined number of days.
Integration Suite MonitoringIf using SAP Integration Suite or MBC, file polling and iFlow execution monitoring can detect missing files and trigger alerts.
Custom DevelopmentCustom ABAP monitoring is not allowed in Public Cloud; alerts must be handled via BTP or standard tools.
Best-Practice ControlDefine a daily monitoring SOP, assign ownership to Treasury, and escalate if statements are missing beyond SLA.
Overall RecommendationCombine daily Fiori checks, job failure alerts, and BTP-based proactive notifications to avoid unnoticed gaps.

If you find my response helpful, share your feedback. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your support.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: error assign chart of depreciation to company code
entry.content:
Hello @Roshanjena ,

Below is the complete explanation covering issue, reason, correct approach, checks, and alternatives.

 

TopicDetails
Error MessageParallel currency area (currency type 30) missing for area 01 ‚Äì Chart of Depreciation MP41
When It OccursWhile assigning a Chart of Depreciation to a Company Code
Root CauseCompany code has parallel currency type 30 defined, but Depreciation Area 01 in the chart of depreciation does not support this currency type
Why SAP Checks ThisIn S/4HANA, Asset Accounting is fully integrated with Universal Journal (ACDOCA) and must support all company code currencies
Currency Type 30Usually represents a group currency or additional parallel currency
Mandatory RuleLeading depreciation area (01) must exist for all currency types used by the company code
System ValidationSAP validates currency compatibility before allowing CoD assignment
Where to Check Company Code CurrenciesSPRO ‚Üí FI ‚Üí Global Settings ‚Üí Currencies ‚Üí Define Currency Settings for Company Code
Where to Check Depreciation AreasSPRO ‚Üí FI ‚Üí Asset Accounting ‚Üí Valuation ‚Üí Define Depreciation Areas
Missing ConfigurationDepreciation Area 01 is not assigned to currency type 30
Corrective Action (Recommended)Add currency type 30 to depreciation area 01 in the chart of depreciation
Alternative (If Not Required)Remove currency type 30 from company code (rare and usually not recommended)
Impact if UnresolvedChart of depreciation cannot be assigned, asset accounting remains inactive
Best PracticeKeep depreciation area 01 aligned with all FI currencies
Post-Fix StepRe-assign chart of depreciation to the company code

entry.title: Re: How to Show Previous Year (Same Month) Date in Dynami...
entry.content:
Hi @AhmadAzaanFarooqui,

I have tried same requirements but for previous day shows in textbox.

Below code is as per your requirement,

Write below code on initialisation or table result change.

// Get previous year's date in textbox
var d = new Date();

// Set date to previous year
d.setFullYear(d.getFullYear() - 1);

// Get day, month, year
var day = d.getDate();
// var month = d.getMonth();
var year = d.getFullYear();

// Final Formatted date
var formattedDate = day.toString() + " December " + year.toString();

// Apply to Text widget
Text_Date.applyText(formattedDate);
}

 

Note: Just for trial purpose I have hard coded month. 

 

Thank You,

Upvote and like if you find it helpful.

entry.title: Can S4 Cloud ERP Public Cloud support to manage Swiss QR Code Bills
entry.content:
Can S4 Cloud ERP Public Cloud support to manage Swiss QR Code Bills and meet below requirement?

The customer is moving from local AMS ERP to S4 Cloud ERP Public Cloud, emphasized below requirement:

This regulation is of interest to ASC.  QR invoices and adjustments to master data. Maybe interesting for SAP S4 Public Cloud implementation:

Changes in payment transactions QR-bills / payment orders in ISO 20022 format structured addresses mandatory ‚Äì Swiss state law
The most important innovation is the mandatory use of structured addresses in QR-bills as of the 21st November 2025, which requires an adjustment of the master data and software. Here, only structured addresses (address type "S") are allowed in the QR-bills.

As of November 2026 at the latest, structured addresses are also mandatory for all payment orders in ISO 20022 format.

The new standards, which are based on the 2019 version of the ISO 20022 standard, require the splitting of addresses into individual, defined fields (e.g. street, house number, postal code, city, country) instead of the earlier, unstructured text fields.

The aim of this amendment is to increase the efficiency and accuracy of payment transactions and to simplify cross-border and digital payments.

All relevant adjustments have been made by DIAMANT with software version 1.8.02. In addition, as of this software status, the invoicing party is now also transferred from the QR code to the Account Holder field. Previously, this name was only transferred to the Name field of the open item address.

Customer's requirement in original German language: 

√Ñnderungen im Zahlungsverkehr QR-Rechnungen / Zahlungsauftr√§ge im ISO-20022-Format strukturierte Adressen verpflichtend ‚Äì Landesrecht Schweiz
Die wichtigste Neuerung ist die verpflichtende Nutzung strukturierter Adressen in QR-Rechnungen ab dem 21. November 2025, welche eine Anpassung der Stammdaten und Software erfordert. Hier sind nur noch strukturierte Adressen (Adress-Typ ¬´S¬ª) in den QR-Rechnungen erlaubt.
 
Sp√§testens ab November 2026 sind zus√§tzlich dann f√ºr alle Zahlungsauftr√§ge im ISO-20022-Format strukturierte Adressen verpflichtend.

Die neuen Standards, die auf der Version 2019 des ISO 20022-Standards basieren, verlangen die Aufteilung von Adressen in einzelne, definierte Felder (z.B. Stra√üe, Hausnummer, Postleitzahl, Ort, Land) anstelle der fr√ºheren, unstrukturierten Textfelder.

Diese √Ñnderung soll die Effizienz und Genauigkeit im Zahlungsverkehr erh√∂hen und die grenz√ºberschreitenden sowie digitalen Zahlungen vereinfachen.
 
Alle relevanten Anpassungen sind durch den Hersteller DIAMANT mit dem Softwarestand 1.8.02 erfolgt. Zus√§tzlich wird ab diesem Softwarestand nun auch der Rechnungssteller aus dem QR-Code in das Feld Kontoinhaber √ºbernommen ‚Äì bisher war dieser Name nur in das Feld Name der OP-Adresse √ºbernommen worden.
